support_summary: The C-terminal glycine-rich domain of TDP-43 has been shown to mediate direct interaction with several hnRNP proteins, including hnRNP A1. This interaction is critical for the regulation of hnRNP A1 pre-mRNA splicing.

functions.cellular_process: Nuclear TDP-43 binds to the pre-mRNA of hnRNP A1 and modulates its alternative splicing, specifically preventing the inclusion of a cryptic cassette exon (exon 7B).
functions.effect_description: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 function leads to the inclusion of exon 7B in the HNRNPA1 transcript, producing an aggregation-prone isoform called hnRNP A1B.
biological_consequence: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 → Aberrant splicing of hnRNP A1 pre-mRNA → Increased inclusion of cryptic exon 7B → Translation of aggregation-prone hnRNP A1B isoform → Formation of toxic cytoplasmic aggregates → Motor neuron death
specific_effects: Nuclear depletion of TDP-43 results in elevated protein levels of the hnRNP A1B isoform, which has an elongated prion-like domain.
The hnRNP A1B isoform has a greater propensity for fibrillization and aggregation, which is toxic to cells.
In ALS patients with TDP-43 pathology, hnRNP A1B accumulates in the cytoplasm of neurons.
Some studies suggest that TDP-43 gain-of-function mutations can also increase the inclusion of exon 7B.
